journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Feedback linearization-based robust nonlinear control design for hypersonic flight vehicles

article-meta.aff: 1University of New South Wales, Australian Defence Force Academy, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Obaid Ur Rehman, University of New South Wales, Australian Defence Force Academy, Canberra, BC, ACT 2612, Australia. Email: s.obaid.rehman@gmail.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: A new approach to designing a robust nonlinear controller for longitudinal flexible body models of canard configured air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicles with significant couplings and interactions is presented. The methodology uses a robust feedback linearization method to feedback linearize the nonlinear air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicle model with 24 uncertainty parameters. Using this approach, a linearized uncertainty model of the air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicle is obtained in the first step by considering an upper bound on each uncertain parameter. In the second step, a minimax linear quadratic regulator-based velocity and altitude robust tracking controller is synthesized for the linearized model. Simulation studies are conducted using the original nonlinear model of the air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicle with a large flight envelope and time-varying uncertainties. Simulation results show that the feedback linearization-based minimax linear quadratic regulator controller effectively achieves the tracking requirement and robustly stabilizes the air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicle.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last three decades, significant developments have been made in the field of robust control.1 Many different powerful techniques have been developed for the stabilization of linear systems in the presence of uncertainties.2–6 Several control system designs have been proposed for the nonlinear air-breathing hypersonic flight vehicle (AHFV) model,7 and they have been demonstrated to perform well in certain cases.8–13 This problem can be approached by linearizing the model at a given operating point, and once a linear model is obtained, any linear robust controller design technique can be applied. The widely used Jacobian linearization method gives a linearized model for a given nonlinear system at a given equilibrium point. However, if the system dynamics are highly nonlinear or the system deviates significantly from the operating point, then Jacobian linearization may not work effectively.

In order to ensure stability for a wide range of operating points using a linear controller, the idea of feedback linearization attracted considerable attention.14–17 The feedback linearization method linearizes the nonlinear dynamics by linearizing the input–output map for all values of the states
x
, not only at the operating point
x
0
but also in a certain neighborhood of
x
0
as well. After obtaining a linearized input–output map, a linear controller can be designed in combination with the feedback linearization law. The feedback linearization method is widely used in process and aerospace control applications.18,19 The altitude and velocity tracking control design problem for an AHFV using the feedback linearization method, which utilizes nonlinear dynamic inversion techniques,20 is presented in Xu et al.21 and Marrison and Stengel.22

The feedback linearization method can only linearize the nominal model of a system by geometrically canceling the nonlinear terms. The nonlinearities arising from the uncertainties cannot be canceled using the standard feedback linearization method. Therefore, an important condition that is required to be satisfied in the feedback linearization method is that the model of the system must be known exactly. In practical systems, this condition is rarely satisfied, as uncertainties in the system parameters may be present. In the case of an uncertain system model, exact cancelation of the nonlinearities is impossible, and in designing a robust controller for such systems, one needs to deal with the nonlinearities still remaining after feedback linearization.

The nonlinear longitudinal equations of motion for AHFVs23 are characterized by a coupling due to the control surfaces as well as a significant coupling between engine and the flight dynamics. In addition to these couplings, the nonstandard dynamic characteristics of AHFVs and uncertainties in the parameter values make the flight control design of these vehicles highly complex. The AHFV model is difficult to feedback linearize. The reason for this is that the low-order derivatives of the regulated outputs of the AHFV model contain expressions depending on the input and hence exact feedback linearization is not possible.13,24 Even with the simplified model obtained by removing all the couplings as done in Parker et al.,13 it is difficult to feedback linearize the system in the presence of uncertainties.

In this article, we apply a controller design methodology inspired by our previous work25,26 to a recent model of AHFV with coupling and flexibility. The methodology uses a feedback linearization uncertainty modeling approach in order to design a nonlinear robust controller for an AHFV. The main objectives achieved in this article are the derivation of a linearized uncertainty model by considering 24 uncertain parameters and the design of a nonlinear robust tracking controller to track velocity and altitude step reference commands. In contrast to the approach of Parker et al.,13 where the couplings were strategically removed from the nonlinear model, we model these couplings as uncertainties with specified maximum bounds on their magnitude. We assume that the uncertainties arising due to the couplings and uncertain parameters satisfy an integral quadratic constraint condition.27 This approach to modeling allows us to obtain a full vector relative degree system with respect to the regulated outputs of velocity and altitude, which is one of the conditions needed to be satisfied for feedback linearization.17 Finally, a robust nonlinear tracking controller is constructed using a minimax linear quadratic regulator (LQR) approach for the linearized model. Also, the performance of the proposed method is demonstrated using the full flexible model.

The article is organized as follows. “Vehicle model” presents a description of the vehicle model. A simplification of the model and a derivation of the linearized uncertain model are presented in section “Feedback linearization”. Design of a robust nonlinear tracking controller along with simulation results are presented in “Minimax LQR control system design”. Finally, this article is concluded in “Conclusions”, with some final remarks on the proposed procedure. (See Appendix 1 for notation used in this article.)

sec.title: Vehicle model
sec.p: A longitudinal flexible body model of canard configured AHFV with significant couplings and interactions is given below23

The forces and moments in equation (1) do not give a closed representation of the relationship between the control inputs and controlled outputs. In order to obtain a tractable model for the purpose of control design, these forces and moments are replaced with curve-fitted approximations in Sigthorsson and Serrani,23 which is known as a curve-fitted model (CFM). The CFM has been derived by assuming a flat earth and unit vehicle depth and retains the relevant dynamical features of the actual model and also offers the advantage of being analytically tractable.23 Approximations of the forces and moments are given as follows
The coefficients obtained from fitting the curves are given as follows; here, we remove the function arguments for the sake of brevity

represent forebody turn angle and aftbody vertex angle, respectively. The presence of input terms in the low-order derivatives of the outputs and uncertainty in the system make feedback linearization of the models (1) to (3) a challenging task. In this article, we approach this problem in a robust way such that all the uncertainties are lumped together and can be written in a way that is useful for controller synthesis. Using this approach, we derive a control-oriented linearized uncertainty model (CLUM) for an AHFV. In this study, 24 inertial and aerodynamic parameters are considered to be uncertain. Furthermore, using the derived CLUM, a robust minimax LQR controller is synthesized to track velocity and altitude step input commands. Simulation results using the CFM and varying uncertain parameters are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the CLUM and minimax control design method.

sec.title: Feedback linearization
sec.p:
In order to obtain the model in a form suitable for feedback linearization, a simplification has been made to the CFM (see equations (1) to (3) as given in Rehman et al.26), and we expect that the simplified model will closely approximate the real model. The simplification of the model is necessary because we want to get rid of the input terms in the low-order derivatives during the feedback linearization procedure. In this simplification, we represent the flexible states and the input coupling terms as uncertainties. In this model, a canard is used to cancel the lift–elevator coupling. However, in practice, an ideal interconnect gain is hard to achieve and thus exact cancelation of the lift–elevator coupling is not possible;29 therefore, the interconnect gain

sec.title: Minimax LQR control system design
sec.p: The minimax optimal control method is an extension of the LQR optimal control method for a class of uncertain systems. A minimax optimal controller provides robust stability as well as robust performance for a system with structured uncertainty by incorporating the uncertainty bound directly into the controller synthesis. Furthermore, minimax optimal control minimizes the maximum value of a quadratic cost function and gives an optimized controller for a selected cost function. The quadratic cost function for equation (15) is selected as follows

where
Q =

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p:
Simulation studies for the proposed controller have been conducted using the CFM. In addition to the uncertainty included in the parameters, to simulate the mass reduction with the consumption of fuel, the mass
m
is also varied with time by
30 %
of its uncertain value during the simulation. Several cases with different combinations of uncertainties have been considered in our simulation studies. For the sake of brevity, the results for only one combination of uncertainties are given here, in which the parameters
m
and
I
yy
take their minimum possible values and all other uncertain parameters take their maximum possible values. The reference command input is generated by filtering a step through a first-order prefilter with time constant a few times smaller than the settling time of the regulated output. The simulation results for a 30.48 m/s (100 ft/s) step change in velocity and 607 m (2000 ft) step change in altitude, are shown in Figure 1. The results show that tracking of velocity and altitude has been achieved with no steady-state errors in the nominal case as well as with uncertainties. We also present a large flight envelope simulation using the proposed controller. In this simulation, the uncertain parameters are randomly chosen to allow for 20% uncertainty in their nominal values. Simulation results for the velocity and altitude trajectories are presented in Figure 2. The results show that the given velocity and altitude commands are successfully tracked and all the other states and control inputs remain within the given flight envelope.

caption.p: Response to a step change in (a) velocity and (b) altitude. The solid line shows the response with the nominal model, the dashed line shows the response with 10% uncertainty, and the dotted-dashed line shows the response with 20% uncertainty.
Velocity and altitude tracking responses using the minimax LQR controller.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a linearized uncertainty model based on a curve-fitted nonlinear model for an AHFV is developed. The developed model is then used to design a nonlinear robust controller for an AHFV. The simulation results with the flexible CFM confirm the effectiveness of the methodology considered here. It is also demonstrated that the proposed controller gives a stable response even with a larger set of uncertainties than the set of uncertainties considered during the design. This approach also effectively deals with time-varying uncertainty. The proposed method enables the control system designer to feedback linearize the nonlinear model of the AHFV even with interactions and couplings and simplifies the complexity of the controller synthesis problem. Also, a large flight envelope simulation result is presented for large velocity and altitude reference commands.
